thread.title: Tight ends' emergence this season is a positive sign for Podcast
thread.title_full: Tight ends' emergence this season is a positive sign for LSU: Podcast | NOLA.com

author: Randy Rosetta, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Tight ends' emergence this season is a positive sign for Podcast
text:
There haven't been a whole lot of bells and whistles with the LSU offense so far this season, and for good reason considering that Leonard Fournette is fueling most of what the Tigers do.
But there have been some hints of a wrinkle or two, including the inclusion of the tight end a little more often. It's only been four receptions so far, one for a Colin Jeter touchdown, but it seems like quarterback Brandon Harris is looking to the tight ends on a more regular basis than the Tigers have the last several seasons.
How could incorporating the tight ends even more enhance the Tigers' offense? To help answer that question, former LSU standout Richard Dickson joined me on 'Tiger Topics with Randy Rosetta' on Friday.
Dickson is the best tight end in recent Tigers' history, a second-team All-SEC pick in both 2006 and 2008. The Ocean Springs, Miss., native ranks as the most productive tight end in school history with 90 receptions for 952 yards and 10 touchdowns -- all program records for that position.
Though Dickson had plenty of highlights as a four-year starter, his biggest moments might've come in the 2008 BCS National Championship Game when he caught a pair of touchdown passes from Matt Flynn in the Tigers' 38-24 triumph over Ohio State.
